msg: Discussion of smart contract designs and applications.

The main goal of this workgroup will be to give an academic perspective to this research topic and in parallel make clear to users, developers, researchers, businessmen, decision makers and others interested in smart contracts practical ways to utilize them on the different DLTs that are under the Hyperledger umbrella and explore all potentials from deploying them in everyday software solution scenarios.

Hi @walmon and @diestrin. Thank you for joining the group! Apart from the docs you can take a look here https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/SCWG/Smart+Contracts+Taxonomy+Categories it is the ongoing work about categorization of SCs. I am happy to announce the first finished work product of the group, the taxonomy ver 1.0! Based on we started new work products so people with different backgrounds and interests can contribute in parallel. You are all welcome to review the material and comment.

Hello all, 

Here is some info on the Hyperledger Grid project that I mentioned in yesterday's meeting - https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/grid

Hello all, 

Here is some info on the Hyperledger Grid project that I mentioned in yesterday's meeting - https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/grid

Feel free to stop by the #grid room if you have any questions or would like to learn more :thumbsup:
Thanks Patrick, you are very welcome to give us some more information how can we use it for the use case the WG will choose to work on in our next meeting

So, main intent of Grid is as follows:

```Provide reference implementations of supply chain-centric data types, data models, and smart contract based business logic – all anchored on existing, open standards and industry best practices.```

With that in mind if there are existing standards around the use case we decide upon then perhaps Grid could be a good home to define those reference implementations?
I added the Hyperledger Blog Post template to today's meeting minutes and here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ANQdRlk1Pv214a-jxk5Yw_IYIYiQhDB7zELrIzQlbrU/edit
@KellyCooper Thanks! Let's all start using it for our posts

Call for volunteers: Smart Contracts set up the beginning of an Annotated Bibliography on Smart Contracts, per our meeting conversation. Please select 1+ articles of interest and annotate, based on the example at the top of the wiki page. The purpose of the AB is to build a research repository for white papers, personal learning, and dissemination of the Smart Contracts Working Group. Feel free to add additional articles of interest. https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/SCWG/Smart+Contracts+Annotated+Bibliography
Please see the first couple of sentences in a potential Smart Contracts blog. Thoughts? https://wiki.hyperledger.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=24772775

It has been a tradition on all HL calls to keep the time constant for all participants who have daylight savings time. This is because most of the participants are from countries with DST. With the Smart Contract WG time change for DST participants; you now collide with CMSIG calls which happen at 10 am EST (15:00 UTC).

In our meeting we discussed selecting a BPMN application. I have been using LucidChart and am now experimenting with free/open source. I started with Cawemo. This article notes 15 to consider: https://solutionsreview.com/business-process-management/the-top-15-free-and-open-source-bpm-software/

We are asking that all projects and groups help us create a 5 minute video about your group so that we can promote it afterward. Hi everybody, I am facing a problem to start the zoom meeting. It requires a Hyperledger login account which I don't have so I cannot start the SCWG call...
@Silona Can you please give me a hint? Until last time I was able to use the host's secret password, the new zoom software requires a full login to Host a meeting
I am attaching the screen that prevents me from joining and claiming host. When I login with my personal account I am redirected to my personal meeting room and not to Hyperledger's meeting room.

The Linux Foundation’s CommunityBridge engineers are working on a tool to measure the health of critical open source projects and one of the key areas identified is QA Testing.  They request that our communities provide  honest and detailed information on testing tools and methodologies you use in your projects for us to come up with a detailed analysis, which they will share with all respondents and projects. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/9H5G2GV. It’s only 5 questions long.
Hi everybody, I am on a business trip and will not be back for our bi-weekly meeting. Is there anyone who would like to run it?

Last time we discussed about BPMN models and DAML language and how these can be used to create a general for our bicycle use case. This discussion was about to continue today, but I unfortunatelly will not make it
I have a conflict with work and also will be unable to attend.

hi everyone, i am interested in creating a comparison of the different implementation of smart contracts across the hyperledger frameworks;
eg. attempting the same functionality across fabric, sawtooth, iroha, etc.

Hi @kenty, great! We have been working on a use case and the implementation of the same smart contract across different HL frameworks was the goal. You can have a look here https://wiki.hyperledger.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=24777829 and here https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/SCWG/BPMN+-+Bicycle+Use+Case for specific information and I am at your disposal for additional info. You can also propose another use case. Don't hesitate to contact me by any means, here or by email

thank you @st  :grinning:  I am a fabric developer for healthcare SIG and we have already compared fabric vs sawtooth for eConsent:
https://github.com/hyperledger-labs/patient-consent

we are looking at aries/indy and then iroha
